results.title: Look & book: arts & entertainment video directory
results.creator_credit: Ron Cummings, Gary Gray, Irene Krumins and Raceplay
results.brief_description: A video catalogue of forty-five groups and artists who are available to perform at all types of venues including school functions and fetes. A wide range of performers are shown, covering such areas as: magic, mime, clowns, rock, country, folk and bush bands, cabaret, comedy, jazz and blues, guitars, piano and chamber orchestas, puppet theatre, dance and movement, vocal peformance and poetry.

results.title: We don't make him special
results.creator_credit: Peter Brighton, Joan Reidy, Marjorie Fisher and I E A
results.brief_description: The story of the integration into life’s normal activities of a Down’s syndrome child as related by his mother. The acceptance of the child into the school community is effectively portrayed enabling the program to be utilised by a school contemplating the integration of disabled students. A positive program that supports the belief that the whole community benefits from the integration of disabled people into society.

results.title: It's OK to be deaf
results.creator_credit: Peter Brighton and Institute of Educational Administration
results.brief_description: Records the attempts by the mother of a profoundly deaf student to obtain adecuate schooling for her daughter within a normal school environment. Underlines the importance in particular of not treating children with hearing impairment as different from children without hearing impairments.

results.title: Handicap is something you put on a horse
results.creator_credit: Peter Brighton, Joan Reidy, Marjorie Fisher and I E A
results.brief_description: A documentation of the successful integration of a physically disabled person into the field of journalism. Stresses the importance of commencing the integration pocess at an early age and mantaining the integrated contact as the dissabled person matures.

results.title: Attitudes are everything
results.creator_credit: Peter Brighton and Institute of Educational Administration
results.brief_description: A young boy is integrated into a primary school in the Dandenongs. He suffers from chronic tuberous sclerosis and his disabilities include lack of speech and motor dysfuntion of the hands. This video reflects the change in his mother’s attitude as he progresses in his school life. Indicates how integration can be a most positive achievement for all those concerned given a sympathetic and helpful environment.

results.title: Carried away
results.creator_credit: Vonnie von Helmolt, Michael Scott and Destiny Deacon
results.brief_description: A combination of animation and live-action which celebrates the creative process. A stylised exercise using black and white photographs to represent reality and coloured overlays representing flights of fantasy. The artist learns by trial and error to take possession of his creative energy. Useful in the areas of art, media studies and as a stimulus to discussion in English classes.

results.title: Australian bushrangers: Years 7-10. Pt. 3
results.brief_description: Uses extracts from early Australian feature films which recreate the incidents in the era 1790-1880 to focus on the question “Why do we choose an outlaw who was a robber and murderer as our national hero?” Gives details of the life of the Kelly Gang and their dealings with the law.

results.title: Australian bushrangers: Yrs 7-10. Parts 1 & 2
results.brief_description: Looks in detail at two eras of Australian bushranging. Uses extracts from feature films which recreate the incidents in the era 1790-1880 to focus on the question “Why have we glamorised bushrangers?” Part 1. “The Convict bolters” Bushranging in Australia started in the convict era. Convicts who broke out were known as bolters. The program focuses on the reasons the convicts bolted and gives information about some of the bolters. Part 2. “The Wild colonial boys” With the end of transportation bushranging moved into a new era. Bushrangers became associated with daring, bravado, defiance of authority and chivalry. Gives names and details of several of the “new” bushrangers. Overall the bushrangers are shown as thieves and murderers who inflict terror and destruction on the public. Companion volume to “Australian bushrangers. Part 3”

results.title: Australian gold rushes. - Years 4-6.
results.brief_description: An edited version of “Australian gold rushes. Yrs. 7-10”. Provides a general overview of the Australian gold rush period 1850-1900. It is presented in three segments: 1. “Discoveries”. - 2. “Gold rushes, 1800-1900”. - 3. “Mining methods”. Consists of re-enactments, segments from early Australian feature films and stills from the period.

results.title: Australian bushrangers: Years 4-6
results.brief_description: This program is in three sections. 1. “Convict bolters”, 2. “Wild colonial boys”, 3. “The Kelly gang” and focuses on the question “Why have we glamorised bushrangers? Uses extracts from early Australian feature films which recreate the incidents of the era 1790-1880. The bushrangers are shown as outlaws who inflicted terror and destruction on the public. This program is an edited version of “Australian bushrangers. Yrs. 7-10”
